Award.AwardTitle: AGU Chapman Conference Low-Frequency Waves in Space Plasmas; September 1-5, 2014
Award.AbstractNarration:
This is a proposal to support student and young researcher travel to the AGU Chapman Conference on Low-Frequency (ULF, ELF and VLF) Waves in Space Plasmas. Chapman Conferences are topical meetings sponsored by the American Geophysical Union that are designed to provide opportunities for detailed scientific discussion that is not possible at large meetings such as the Fall AGU meeting. Approximately 130 scientists are expected to attend the conference. Approximately 20% of the attendees will be students and young researchers just beginning their careers.

The objective of the conference will be to develop a deeper understanding of the fundamental physics of low-frequency waves, including the generation and propagation mechanisms and the interaction of the waves with magnetospheric thermal plasma and energetic particles. The latter is important for space weather studies.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Chapman Conference on Low-Frequency Waves in Space Plasmas concluded with several successful outcomes. The meeting, with the interdisciplinary character among the different communities in space, was successfully attempted and completed. This is the first time the space community was provided a full week conference on this subject. The conference provided a unique opportunity for 117 space scientists from 19 countries and at various career stages to present research and share ideas.  Attendees indicated that the conference broadened their perspective of the topic.  For one student, the travel grant provided an opportunity for her first trip abroad and she was able to present her research. Another grant recipient indicated the conference was a success for him because almost all active researchers in the field presented at the conference.

 

The Chapman Conference has produced two publications. An AGU Monograph containing 28 chapters and 528 pages is currently in press. The title of the book is, “Low-Frequency Waves in Space Plasma” and will be published in the winter of 2015. The ISBN is 978-1-119-05495-5. The conference also produced a special issue in the Journal of Geophysical Research-Space Physics which focused solely on the conference topic.

 

Thanks to the support from the NSF grant, the conference hardly lost significant contribution from many of young students and senior scientists.
